reviewText: Big G fans disappointed by the apparent cancellation of Media Blasters' "Godzilla Vs. Megalon" Blu-Ray can find solace in Echo Bridge's terrific new release of "Godzilla Vs. Biollante." This 1989 Toho production was the first (of many) sequels in the studio's `80s/'90s "second wave" of Godzilla epics, and the only one domestically controlled by Miramax. In an amazing occurrence that's nearly inconceivable given Miramax's penchant for hacking up overseas imports, Harvey & Bob's editors didn't take the shears out to "Biollante" and basically left it intact from its original Japanese version - dubbing excepted, of course. Echo Bridge's Blu-Ray debut of the film - which sports Godzilla taking on a giant, Audrey II-like plant - looks really good, with a genuine 1080p transfer and both 5.1 DTS MA Japanese (subtitled) and a monophonic English dubbed track on-hand. Extra features are also included, most notably a 50-minute subtitled Japanese documentary. The 1080p transfer is quite good and the entire package attractively priced.
summary: Bargain Blu-Ray Fun for Godzilla Buffs

reviewText: A great follow-up to "Godzilla 1985". SYNOPSIS: Terrorists steal G-cells from the wreckage of Tokyo. A scientist, Dr. Shiragami, loses his  daughter Erika in an unlikely lab explosion at the lab where he works. Five  years later, he merges her DNA with a rose bush. General Kiroki recruits  people, including Colonel Gondo, to make Anti-Nuclear Energy Bacteria, a  weapon hopefully to be used against Godzilla upon his return. Dr. Shiragami  joins the team and merges Erika's DNA/rosebush cells with Godzilla cells.  One night at Dr. Shiragami's, Bio-Major, a company that tried to steal  G-cells earlier on, once again tries to steal--this time information on  Anti-Nuclear Energy Bacteria. A Saradian agent, SSS9, ambushes them,  because he wants it too. A huge tentacle kills one Bio-Major officer, and  the other officer jumps out a window in order to escape. The strange  tentacle nearly kills SSS9, but SSS9 cuts the tentacle in two with a pocket  knife. In the morning, a fellow scientist working on the Anti-Nuclear  Energy Bacteria project discovers what Shiragami's done. A psychic, Miki  Saegusa, and her friend run a school for psychic children. They ask what  their dream was last night, and they keep having the same dream every night  since then and every night it's become clearer. They were asked to  illustrate their dream and it turns out to be Godzilla coming out of a  volcano. Miki senses Godzilla in Mt. Mihara. Bio-Major threatens the  Japanese government to give them the A.N.E.B. (Anti-Nuclear Energy  Bacteria), or else they will detonate Mt. Mihara with explosives, thus  causing Godzilla to escape. An explosion rocks the land from Mt. Mihara, a  warning explosion. So Colonel Gondo and the fellow scientist go to get it,  and give him the A.N.E.B. To deactivate the explosives and their timer,  they must go in back of the man's truck. Just then, SSS9 attacks, and the  trucker tries to get away, but SSS9 shoots a tire of the truck and the  truck topples over. As Gondo tries to deactivate the explosives, SSS9  steals the A.N.E.B. They can't stop the explosives and Godzilla is released  once again. However, a huge form named Biollante has the soul of Erika. It  has formed in Lake Ashino, in Dr. Shiragami's backyard. It has millions of  the tendrils that killed the Bio-Major guy earlier on. Meanwhile out at  sea, air craft carriers and helicopters attack Godzilla, but they are  destroyed. Super X2, equipped with a fire mirror that can repel Godzilla's  radioactive heat ray twice as powerful, is sent out and overwhelms  Godzilla, who dives underwater. Biollante calls Godzilla and Godzilla  emerges from the depths of the sea. Super-X2 fires off torpedoes, and then  their fire mirror is badly damaged. Godzilla then burns the Super-X2 with a  heat ray, and is not fased by its missiles as a counterattack. Godzilla  hits Super-X2 with his tail and Super-X2 is badly damaged and will have to  be piloted back to base by the army. Godzilla hears Biollante taunting it  and heads to Lake Ashino, and he and Biollante do battle. We are informed  by Shiragami that they are both the same creature, bearing the same cells,  and are not siblings. Godzilla wins the battle, roasting Biollante on fire  with heat rays, but not after Biollante uses his mouthed tendrils to her  every advantage. Godzilla eventually emerges in Osaka and destroys it, and  when a mission involving A.N.E.B.-loaded rocket launchers fails, Colonel  Gondo is killed, as he was in the operation and had one of the key rocket  launchers. However, the A.N.E.B. rockets did hit Godzilla and he was  infected by it. Godzilla heads to the countryside, where Dr. Shiragami  hopes that by stepping on particular mines, artifical lightning is formed  and attacks Godzilla and lowers his body temperature (or heightens it, I  can't remember) so the A.N.E.B. can take effect. Godzilla destroys lines of  army tanks, missile-launcher mounted tanks, and maser cannon-mounted tanks,  and helicopters. Then, an even more powerful Biollante arrives for revenge  on what Godzilla did earlier. Biollante sprays Godzilla with burning sap,  similar to what occurred earlier in the Lake Ashino battle at the hands of  a mouthed tendril. The A.N.E.B. takes effect after Godzilla nearly destroys  Biollante. Godzilla retreats to the ocean and literally falls in to get his  bearings together. Biollante dies and Erika leaves her inhuman embodiment  to head to Haven. Dr. Shiragami watches in awe, but is killed by SSS9. SSS9  steps on a mine which generates artificial lightning, after being chased in  a car and on foot by the other protagonist--the scientist. All is well as  the scientist and his girlfriend stay united, and Godzilla leaves Japan.  Then the moral of the story is shared as Dr. Shiragami's corpse is shown in  an army medical tent. REVIEW: One of the good Heisei Godzilla films.  However some parts of the film were rather boring, but the special effects  and music make up for that. The idea for reintroducing Super X is rather  stupid and campy, but has positive and negative edges to it. Godzilla still  bears his "Heisei" roar which he first acquired in Godzilla 1985,  the previous film. I was only a few years of age when I rented this from  Blockbuster, and in addition I rented 1957's "Godzilla Raids  Again", which is a very scarce Godzilla video, wouldn't all fellow  G-fans agree? C'mon, G-fans, I know you're out there! E-mail me.
summary: The Heisei series has officially started

reviewText: This is the weirdest Godzilla movie I have ever seen.  This isn't just Godzilla rampaging; there are plots and subplots galore, making it the most complex, confusing movie in the whole series.  The action picks up where Godzilla 1985 left off; scientists collect some Godzilla cells from the scene, only to have it stolen by some mysterious guys, who in turn have it stolen from them.  The cells make their way to a fictitious Arab nation to be used for genetic research.  The scientist in charge never gets to start work, however, because the lab gets blown up (along with his daughter).  Five years later, one set of bad guys rigs up a series of explosions that free Godzilla.  The government hires yet another lab to make a bacteria that will destroy nuclear energy, hoping they can use the bacteria to defeat Godzilla.  The scientist I mentioned agrees to help the effort in exchange for a week's time working with some other Godzilla cells.  He combines the regenerative Godzilla cells with some flower cells, and before you know it there is a gigantic plant out in the bay.  That's not really the weird part, though.  Although no one at all questions how or why he did it, the scientist somehow combined the spirit of his dead daughter with the flower cells.  Thus, the "monster" Biollante is part flower, part female scientist, and part Godzilla.  All of this leads up, of course, to a fight between Biollante (with its dangerous vines and Godzilla-mouth appendages) battling Godzilla while the Japanese attempt to thwart the big lizard for good.You would think that Godzilla would have a pretty easy time with a plant for a foe, but of course this plant shares Godzilla's own genetic makeup.  The deeply-layered plots are a little too murky for my tastes, and the abilities of Biollante border on the ridiculous, but the special effects are by far the best of all Godzilla movies up to this point.  The technology used in this film far surpasses that of previous movies, even though I must say I rather miss scenes using blatantly obvious models.  Godzilla's head does strike me as a little small, but most people will probably like the new look.This movie is the first one released after Godzilla 1985, so it marks the real beginnings of the new Godzilla series in which Godzilla is all about destruction for its own sake.  I would recommend this movie for the special effects alone, but most people should also appreciate a plot that is vastly different from what has come before (it's confusing, but it's not necessarily a bad storyline).  I would note a couple of other things, and because of the dubbing I don't know if these were added for the American version or if they also appeared in the original Japanese release.  First, as far as I know this is the first Godzilla film featuring some foul language--it's just PG language, but it was sort of strange to hear it here.  Second, there is one moment in the film that is completely unforgivable, but all I can say is that it involves a campy, totally artificial sound added quite unnecessarily to a scene.
summary: A really weird storyline but terrific special effects

reviewText: This Review is for;Godzilla vs. BiollanteDespite what the slip cover indicates, the DVD of "Godzilla vs. Biollante" appears to be a full screen presentation with 5.1 & 2.0 Japanese audio tracks as well as a 1.0 (mono) English dubbed track. No commentaries or trailers. There are two bonus features; "Making of Godzilla vs. Biollante" (49 minutes) & "Behind the Design" (about 3 minutes). Both featurettes are in Japanese audio with English subtitles. "Behind the Design" is simply a brief 3-minute featurette about the design of Biollante with designer interviews & footage of their concept drawings & models."The Making of Godzilla vs Biollante" 49-minute main featurette is the one to watch. It is a series of inteviews with writer Shinichiro Kobayashi, writer-director Kazuki Ohmori, SFX director Koichi Kwakita, SFX cameraman Kenichi Eguchi, SFX lighting director Kaoru Saito and numerous film-making sequences. We get shots of Toho studios giant, water tank where the actor in the Godzilla suit gets hammered with pyro explosions while a camera crew circles around in a raft (we also get to see a camera man lose his balance & fall into the water). We get to see three deleted scenes including Godzilla wondering in the water next to some hills covered with very colorful flowers generated by Biollante, a miniature boat getting attacked by some of Biollante's tentacles, and an interesting brief "animation sequence" when Godzilla gets consumed by Biollante (and then the animation scene returns to the regular footage).We get to see numerous crew members operating the wires to move Biollante's numerous tentacles (more challenging than operating Ghidorah). We get to see remote control helicopters & tanks while the crew wanders around them. We get scenes of the set crew who prepare the miniature buildings for Godzilla to destroy (some of the buildings are over 400 lbs). We see a brief press photo shoot on the set as the directors & one of the actresses take photos with Godzilla. We get to see how matt drawings were used on some of the sets. We see numerous RAW special effect shots & how the same shots look like in the final film for comparison.Note that there was very minimal CGI was used in this film. Mostly special effects done the old-fashioned way using miniatures, remote control vehicles, matt paintings, Biollante's numerous parts controlled by wires, & Godzilla operated in a rubber suit by a suit actor! Overall most of the videos presented look like they were filmed on personal video cameras as I see the date 1989 stamped on most of the view finders. Absolutely one of the BEST special featurette to watch on any US release of Godzilla and I own every one of them. Just waiting for "Return of Godzilla (or Godzilla 1985)" to complete my collection!
summary: Great Special Features Included, but Main Feature Appears to be Full Screen!

reviewText: Many people are happy with this official release of Godzilla vs Biollante. That's fine, but I wanted to write this review, not so much on the movie itself, but some of the technical differences of the official release, the bootleg DVD, and the U.S. VHS release. Both the official and bootleg have the same presentation of the movie itself with opening and closing credits in Japanese, regardless of whether you select the English track or not on this version. The VHS has the opening and closing credits in English, including the title itself GODZILLA vs BIOLLANTE, not the title in Japanese with the English title subtitled below. The English dub for this and the VHS is the same. The audio options for this release are Japanese 5.1 surround, Japanese 2.0 stereo, and English 1.0 mono. The bootleg is Japanese audio only with an option for English subtitles or no subtitles. This version has two English subtitle options. One is what the actors are actually saying and the other is the on-screen display of the English dub. The VHS and this DVD have no trailers. The bootleg has a colorized clip of Godzilla 54 and two Godzilla vs Biollante trailers set to the music of Akira Ifukube before the start of the movie and one G v B after the movie followed by a 45 minute behind the scenes documentary which is basically the same as the one on the official release. The differences are the bootleg has it broken up in 19 chapters with no English subtitles. This DVD has it as one chapter only, take it or leave it, but at least there is an option for English subtitles plus an additional 5 minutes of footage at the beginning of the feature not on the bootleg version. The bootleg's only audio sounds the same as the 5.1 Surround of this release. The bootleg has no menu. Just put the DVD in and it will play automatically. Personally I like the bootleg best. reviewText: With this LOOOOONG overdue official DVD release, I could not wait to review the movie itself.  The review of the actual dvd may not be all you expect as Destroy All Monsters had been. As a film,however, Godzilla vs. Biollante is one of the, if not best in the entire Godzilla series.  The effects are very good...and Biollante in all forms is a difficult beast to animate.  The cinematography however, helps hide some defects as it is grainy in an almost realistic way.  The Godzilla suit also is one of the best and the monster is animated in many different ways that show him as an animal who is a force of nature, but really doesn't realize it.  Sometimes the movements of Godzilla seem as if he's a cat playing with a piece of yarn.  Other times he turns and roars as if annoyed.  The fight sequences are not long, but well done.  The story is somewhat compelling and not entirely predictable.  Some of the characters were developed nicely.  Dr. Shiragami comes off almost like Dr. Frankenstein, but the actor is too emotionless.  In fact much of the acting (especially the American actors as usual) is pretty bad....surprisingly, it doesn't hurt the movie at all, yet gives it a familiar feel.  I could write a lot more, but if anyone hasn't seen this it would ruin it.  It is entirely possible as this movie had little hype here due to an unfamiliar monster fighting Godzilla....the box office draw in Japan was very low, which encouraged them to bring back familiar foes such as Ghidorah and Mothra (who would appear in the next 2 films and draw much better at the box office).  The irony now being that if Biollante were brought back in a Godzilla movie the fans would love it!I hope you enjoy it as much as I do!ADDENDUM: I ordered this through Amazon for 4.99...how can you go wrong?  You can't!  The extras include a documentary w/ SUBTITLES..on the making of...this includes a lot of the extra material that was edited out and you can see why it was.  Apparently this movie had more extra footage than any other Godzilla movie.  I have all of this w/ a Japanese version, but the extras don't have subtitiles and I really enjoy hearing the point of view of the staff working on the film..it is very insightful...and then when you watch it; after seeing all of that, it makes the film that much more incredible.  Biollante is a magnificent monster and it is amazing what they were able to pull off with it (her?)  The ONLY shortcoming is in the extra regarding the designs; they ONLY did Biollante and the Super X2...NOT Godzilla....which is a bummer ONLY because it's one of the finest G suits in the entire series.  Seeing how they animate it in the making of feature, however, is amazing to see...they were creating a lot while they were filming and in a similar fashion to 'Star Wars' they not only pulled it off, but they set standards which future Kaiju features would try to live up to.If you are a Godzilla fan, you already have this movie; but for this price, you want the extras.

reviewText: "Godzilla vs. Biollante," the second film of the more modern 'Heisei' series and the 17th film overall, was the direct result of an open story contest sponsored by Tomoyuki Tanaka and Toho Studios.  It was a  clever way to broaden the scope of future films and generate media and fan  interest.  Tanaka also believed that Godzilla needed an enemy to battle,  preferably a completely new and original one.Over 5,000 entries were  received - many from outside Japan - as word of the contest spread.  In  1986, the winner was selected.  The winning treatment was written by a  dentist and part-time screenwriter named Shinichiro Koybayashi.The film  would not go before the cameras for another 3 years.  When it was filmed in  1989, the final screenplay for "Godzilla vs. Biollate" was  written by the director, Kazuki Omori, from Koybayashi's  treatment."Godzilla vs. Biollate" is a very differant Godzilla  film, perhaps the most poetic of the series.  And Biollate is a very  differant foe for Godzilla.The action begins mere hours after the events  of the previous film - "Godzilla 1985" - , amoung the ruins of  Tokyo.  But the drama soon ranges from the mythical Arabian country of  Saradia to the laboratories of a sinister American pharmaceutical company  to the classrooms of the Japan Psionic Center - were scientist study  children who possess extrasensory powers.One of the clairvoyants soon  takes center stage.  17-year-old Miki Saegusa - played by Megumi Odaka -  would become a central character in the future Godzilla films, returning in  1991's "Godzilla vs. King Ghidorah."The music, composed by  Koichi Sugiyama and David Howell, could have been better, but has solid  themes for Godzilla and the Super-X II.Other highlights are a  well-staged sea battle between Godzilla and a fleet of Japanese warships,  and a tank and laser-cannon battle in a heavy rainstorm.

reviewText: I'm unapologetic about my love for Godzilla. I enjoy his films both for their camp value *and* because I think they're often legitimately good examples of science fiction. Indeed, the Godzilla series features a distinctive blend of big sci-fi ideas, social commentary, and wacky action that's simply impossible to find anywhere else.Generally speaking, Godzilla fans tend to prefer the older (1950s-1970s) films to those that came later. However, I'm a big fan of 1980s-1990s Godzilla fare, and "Godzilla vs. Biollante" is one of Toho's best films of the period. The very creative script blends together a wide range of elements, including creepy scientific experiments and international espionage. And while the pacing sometimes drags early on, once Godzilla pops out of his volcano hideout and starts wrecking things, the film becomes consistently entertaining.Naysayers may mock the "old school" special effects, but I tend to find the visuals in Godzilla movies to be (in no particular order) charming, cool, and sometimes even exciting. In fact, the huge, tentacled Biollante creature in this movie looks downright awesome, and is arguably the best-looking Godzilla opponent ever. (Besides, it's not like the CGI you see in contemporary movies is exactly "convincing." For example, I enjoyed the special effects in The Avengers, but never for a moment did I believe that Robert Downey Jr. was really flying around in a metal suit and fighting aliens!)As for the Blu Ray itself - considering that it's so cheap, I'm both surprised and pleased to report that the print is halfway decent (given the age of the source material). The Blu Ray also comes with some interesting making-of features, focusing particularly on the genesis of the film's script and the design for Biollante. While it's hardly the crown jewel of my collection, this is certainly a pretty decent release.So, to expand upon the formula I included in my subject line: Godzilla + giant mutant rose + okay cheap Blu Ray = a win for one and all.
summary: Cheap Godzilla Blu Ray = A Win

reviewText: This 1989 entry was the second film of the Heisei Godzilla series ("Godzilla 1985" being the first), and should be commended for its ambition, although it is by no means a perfect film.  Like many other  G-films, it's a hybrid of a giant monster movie and an environmental  morality play: in this case, a warning against the dangers of genetic  engineering.  Once again, Godzilla returns to face off against another  massive rival, Biollante, which is a cross between a rose bush and a  radioactive Godzilla-Cell.  The idea of the big G tangling with a giant  plant is a good one, although the initial Biollante design falls a little  short--the victim of budget constraints, as is often the case in these sort  of movies.  The dubbing is actually pretty good, although the action moves  somewhat slowly at times.  Godzilla himself is impressive, and the battles  between himself the Super X-2 battle machine, as well as Biollante (in its  massive, final form at the end of the movie) are as well.  This is one of  the better entries in the Heisei series.

reviewText: The picture quality on this disc looks like a DVD, not a Blu-ray. Granted, the film is nearly twenty-five years old, they still could have remastered it better then they did. It is not like it looked bad, but a Blu-ray should have looked a lot better.The only English dub on the disc is 1.0 mono. That is pretty lazy. They have a 2.0 stereo and a 5.1 surround audio track on the disc that are both Japanese, requiring English subtitles. They could have at least done a 2.0 stereo track of the English dub. Also, the "Making of" documentary is in Japanese with English subtitles, but with no option to watch it with an English dub.The film's score was very lacking. It was much too happy. There were scenes where Godzilla was trampling and destroying and about to battle, and the music sounded like Sesame Street. All that was needed was classic Godzilla music, and the film would have been so much better. In some places the music which sounded way too happy ruined the experience of the film, by not putting the viewer in the right frame of mind for the scene. Did the musician know he was doing a Godzilla film or was he told he was scoring an episode of Barney and Friends?Last, but not least, the saving grace of this disc, and the reason it is even getting any stars at all is the actual film itself. The plot of this film was absolutely magnificent. It was generally about scientists using Godzilla DNA to create a creature equal in strength and attributes as him to protect the planet from him, and then they would have went into medicinal production with it, as a result of it's healing properties. The original classic, Gojira (aka Godzilla: King of the Monsters, the American version) was about the fears of nuclear warfare, which is what created Godzilla to begin with. This film is about the fears of micro-biology and the possible threat of biological warfare or biological terrorism, which is a true to life danger we face today in a post 9/11 world. In that way, this film is twenty years before it's time. It took the next step in technology from nuclear technology to micro-biological technology, making a nice link both plot and scientifically, to the original film.
summary: Very Well Made Film, Not so Well Made Blu-ray

reviewText: It's Godzilla versus a mutated plant made from his own cells.  What's not to like?  I had this movie on VHS for years but my VCR bit the dust several years ago and I never bothered replacing it due to it being outdated technology, so I've been looking for this movie on DVD for years.  I was so stoked to see it out finally in a region 1 DVD.  I was even more stoked to see the Blu-Ray was only a few dollars more and, since I recently bought a Blu-Ray player, I had to get it.I honestly don't know what all of the complaints are on the Blu-Ray picture (though, I think the majority of the picture complaints are on the DVD.)  I think it looks great, much better than my old VHS copy.  1080p anamorphic widescreen is great.  The Japanese audio is great.  I know this because it starts up, though it threw me for a loop at first because there's a woman at the beginning speaking English.  However, once one of the Japanese people started talking, I realized I had the Japanese track on and that woman was really speaking English and the Japanese text on the screen was the subtitles.  ;)  So, I switched to the English track.  Unfortunately, as others have pointed out, the English is only 1.0 Dolby Digital mono, while you get 5.1 and 2.0 Dolby Digital stereo for the Japanese.  It sounds like they just transferred the original English dubbed audio from when the film was put on VHS in the early 1990s, with no attempt to restore or remaster it.  I would have liked it to be at least remastered audio in 2.0 stereo but, for the price, I can't really complain.  If I'd spent $15 to $20 for this movie, I'd have been mad, though.The movie itself is a gem.  This is the second movie in the Hensei era, the 7-film series that started with The Return of Godzilla (AKA, Godzilla 1985) and ended with Godzilla VS Destroyer.  (there were also some Mothra and Gamera films in the era, but I'm just counting Godzilla films)  Though, if you count the original Godzilla, it's actually an 8-film series since The Return of Godzilla is a direct sequel/reboot that skips the films between it and the original.  The plot in this one is very good, science gone wrong creates a super plant that fights Godzilla.  There's an big international conspiracy that plays throughout the film and I think this is actually one of the better human plots in the G films.  (some of the human plots are downright awful)  And, of course, the special effects, miniature work, costumes and action are great.  This movie also introduces the psychic character Miki Saegusa, who was played by Megumi Odaka.  The character appeared in all of the Hensei Godzilla films except for The Return of Godzilla, which makes her the character to appear the most in any Japanese big monster movie series.So, the movie is a 5/5 for me, though the Blu-Ray is only a 4/5 due to the English audio.

reviewText: For starters the dubbing of this movie was simply atrocious. There wasn't any of that macho man style voice that was found in the first generation Godzilla flicks instead there was a guy who always referred to Godzilla as Godziller. "Yeah it was all good until Godziller came and messed everything up." This was to say the least annoying and the other dubs were also very mediocre.The plot concerns the death of a scientist's wife who somehow becomes reincarnated into a rose that then mutates with the addition of Godzilla (or should I say Godziller)cells. Everybody is trying to get their hands on these Godzilla cells. Agents from a made-up country and of course evil American pharmecuetical companies (well at least those are not made up). Eventually the evil American company blackmails the Japanease to turn over the Godzilla dense mechanism made, made of Godzilla cells, to them or they will blow up the volcano in which Godzilla is trapped. Guess what they do...The monster vs. monster scenes were a bit weak simply because mose of the time Godzilla is fighting a giant flower and his plasma breath does what plasma does to any plant. It burns. However the movie is saved when Biollante turns into a massive mouthed plant monster that can move and is bigger than Godzilla. The special effects are better than those of the original Godzilla movies but some of them are really lame like Erica's accension into the sky.Given that this movie featured the worst dubbing ever and a relatively lame plot with made up countries it does not seem to be a big improvement over the first generation Godzilla films.

reviewText: Godzilla vs Biollante. Before this release, Biollante hasn't been officially available in the USA with the original Japanese language track in tact. I'm pleased to report that not only does the Japanese (and English!) track exist, they appear to have used the remastered Japanese video... even if it isn't amazing.Video:AVC 1080p encoded.The picture, in a word, is soft. I think this is a combination of film stock and the way it was filmed. At this time, I don't believe there is any way that you can make an overly soft film become magically drip with detail. I wish I could report otherwise. Compare the video to my... "international" edition DVD... and the difference is night and day. That's not a fair comparison, but as Biollante hasn't been available as a legitimate US release, it's all I have to compare.Video isn't bad, but it is forgettable.Audio:You can choose between three spoken language options:Japanese: DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1Japanese: Dolby Digital 2.0English: Dolby Digital MonoThe DTS 5.1 is... well, there's little to no directionality, so you might as well switch over to the stereo version if you want to watch in Japanese. It's not as clear, but I found it generally "felt" better to me. Your mileage will vary.Subtitles are optional. You have three options. You can choose to translate just the signs (this is on by default for the English language audio option), you can have SDH (English language subtitles for the English language audio track) and also a literal Japanese translation. For the best experience, if you can't understand Japanese, I would recommend the Japanese 2.0 audio with the literal translation.The English mono feels like such a massive afterthought, like they literally landed at the end of the Blu Ray mastering session and said "whoops! It's an English language country we're releasing this to! Someone find whatever you can and we'll slap it on here." The acting is the typical hammish hilarity you expect, and is typical Godzilla English dub. Couldn't they at least included a stereo English track? I guess that might be asking too much.Extras:These are actually not bad. Both are in standard definition, so your system won't get a work out, but it's generally not something we receive with budget releases.Miramax took the time to give us an English translation (hard coded subtitles) on the 50 minute making of featurette. If you're interested in how Godzilla is made in his homeland, this is a great featurette. Nothing earth shattering, but worth watching.Behind the Design featurette. This is 3 minute filler, and worth watching once. It's nice it was included, but if it weren't there you wouldn't miss it. Not bad, not amazing.Overall:Considering this has never been available in the US and there are questionable "international" editions available easily, it is amazing Miramax gave this one a shot. Honestly, it's not an amazing release. It has some issues that stem from the quality of the master material, so what we have, in my mind, is about as good as we can ever expect. And for me, that's worth 5 stars. Godzilla should be appreciated. If it takes a budget release like this to see it happen, I'm all for it.If you're new to Godzilla, a superior release is the Criterion Blu Ray which I can't recommend enough, and the quality is amazing. Of course, that quality sets the bar so high I'm not sure a budget release could ever contend.Recommended for Godzilla fans, though if you're a fan of spoken English language, you may want to evaluate the value, given the poor mono track offered up.

reviewText: Miki Saegusa might be an odd place to start a Godzilla review but she is a prominent psychic (psy-chick?) character who for better or worse found herself in most of the Heisei Godzilla movies and is a notable returning actor at least to the eyes of the western audience (my wife and I refer to her affectionately as "big ears").  The actress playing Miki is Megumi Odaka and, with her introduction, the supranatural was introduced into Godzilla movies.  To be sure past entries involved the worship of or calling upon deities (think King Seesar for example) but here the focus turns not to the spiritual world that mankind inhabits and lives within but that world which is within mankind, that new age potential of untapped or unrealized human psychic energy.  While we have seen humankind's concerted efforts in trying to stop Godzilla with weapons of physical force in the past here we are presented with something completely new: Miki immobilizes Godzilla momentarily in one scene via her concentration, her mind reaching out and affecting Godzilla's mind!  This is a new era indeed!While the series never came close to a single person standing up to Godzilla quite so effectively again this goes to show you just how far this Godzilla script has gone in creating a wildly different G film.  The G films have always had strong female characters and this is no different but here we also have Godzilla's kaiju nemesis dressed up (if you'll pardon the pun) as a distinctly feminine creature.  Outside of Mothra all other kaiju have been thought of as distinctly male in some fashion but here Biollante, infused with the spiritual soul of our mad scientist's departed daughter, is seen most distinctly in her feminine form as a giant monstrous rose before transforming into the enormous plant-Godzilla hybrid of Biollante that we are so familiar (and enamored--what an awesome creature design) with.  There is a lot of monster action in this movie, much to the fan's delight.  The gaps with the monsters off-screen are never too long and the storyline while they are off-screen is constantly and effectively building to them being on-screen, even as the story gives the necessary human dramas their due.With Godzilla simply looking monstrous (great), a new and intriguing creature in Biollante, decent human drama with some compelling twists in plot, and the military getting its crack at the big G once again with a resouped Super-X2, and with the introduction of a new human series character in Miki Saegusa Godzilla vs. Biollante is an enjoyable and unique entry in the series that has made the terror of Japan so popular across the globe.  Disappointing is there being no commentary track but, still, many thanks to Echo Bridge for bringing this fine and entirely neglected entry to DVD and Blu-Ray (! yes!) after too many long years.

reviewText: It's great to have this released in the U.S., much less on the Blu-Ray format.  The transfer is fine and because of some licensing hangups, my copy has minimal extras.  But considering that I never thought this movie would be released on DVD in the U.S., the whole thing seems a bit miraculous.  I'd give the movie itself three-stars, but I'll throw in a fourth star just for the Blu-Ray effort.I just realized that not only have I seen every Godzilla movie ever made, I now also own all but one of them. If this does anything at all, it qualifies me to state that overall, Godzilla movies aren't very good. I mean, as solid stories go, these G-flicks are not exactly "Wuthering Heights". But, what they are is entertaining. Sometimes for good reasons. Take "Godzilla vs. Biollante". It's a story about Japan, the U.S. and some fictional Middle-Eastern oil rich country trying to out spy each other for control of some Godzilla cells scattered around the destruction from his last stomp through Tokyo.Wow. It is silly. But it's so over the top and so illogical it kept me engaged. This movie contains some absolutely stupid spy-vs-spy action. There's also a countless number of mistakes in the English dub. It's all pretty funny.However, the special effects are pretty good and Biollante is the ugliest but one of the most different kaiju ever committed to film. The big dust up between the two beasts is never really resolved. Godzilla falls face first on the beach only to pop up again and head back out to sea and Biollante turns into some magic environmental pixie dust and floats into the sky. But if you're watching this for the monsters, and that's why you watch Godzilla, this one is worth the time.
summary: A Blu-Ray release?!?  It's a miracle!
